intro: Convert your hourly wage to annual salary in the USA with our comprehensive calculator. Whether you're considering a new job offer, negotiating pay rates, or planning your budget, understanding your annual equivalent salary is crucial for financial planning. This calculator accounts for the US tax system including federal income tax, state income tax, Social Security tax (6.2%), Medicare tax (1.45%), 401(k) contributions, and other common deductions. Based on official 2026 IRS rates and all 50 state tax rates, it provides accurate calculations for hourly workers, part-time employees, and contractors who bill by the hour. Simply enter your hourly rate, hours worked per week, and selected state to see your net take-home pay across different payment periods.
howThisCalculatorWorks: This USA hourly to salary calculator converts your hourly wage to annual, monthly, and weekly equivalents while accounting for US tax deductions. First, it calculates your gross annual salary by multiplying hourly rate × hours per week × 52 weeks. Then it applies 2026 federal income tax using progressive brackets (10%-37%), state income tax based on your selected state (0% in Texas to 13.3% in California), Social Security tax (6.2%), Medicare tax (1.45%), and optional deductions like 401(k) contributions. The result shows both gross and net salary figures so you can understand your true take-home pay. Holiday pay and other benefits are not included in this calculation.

importantConsiderations.title: Important Considerations for Hourly Pay in the USA
points: **Federal Minimum Wage:** $7.25/hour for large employers (2024 rates, may increase)
**State Minimum Wages:** Vary from $7.25 (federal) to $16.90/hour (Washington DC)
**Overtime:** Time-and-a-half for hours over 40/week under FLSA
**Contract Hours:** Your calculation assumes consistent hours throughout the year
**Tax Treatment:** Hourly pay is taxed the same as salary income under federal/state systems
**Benefits:** Many employers offer 401(k) and health insurance to hourly workers

faqs.question: How do I convert hourly pay to annual salary in the USA?
faqs.answer: Multiply your hourly rate by hours worked per week, then by 52 weeks in a year. Then deduct federal income tax, state income tax, Social Security (6.2%), Medicare (1.45%), and other deductions to get your net annual salary.

faqs.question: Does this calculator include holiday pay?
faqs.answer: No, this calculator shows your base hourly conversion. Most US employees are entitled to 10 days paid annual leave (2 weeks), which typically adds about 4% to your annual equivalent salary.

faqs.question: What's the federal minimum wage in the USA?
faqs.answer: The federal minimum wage is $7.25 per hour for large employers. Many states and cities have higher minimum wages - for example, California has $16.90/hour and New York City has $15.00/hour.

faqs.question: How are hourly workers taxed in the USA?
faqs.answer: Hourly pay is treated as salary income and taxed under the federal progressive system with rates from 10%-37%, plus state taxes that vary by location, and FICA taxes (Social Security + Medicare).

faqs.question: Can I include overtime in this calculation?
faqs.answer: This calculator is for your base hourly rate. Use our USA Overtime Pay Calculator for overtime calculations including time-and-a-half and double-time rates.
